name: Jonah Miller
comment info: We can clearly see from the graphs that there are two major trends: women are getting educated much more frequently than men, and the United States it not only in the lower half of the desire for higher quality education, but for the rate of extended education beyond high school as well. This clashes with the common American belief of them being quite the prestigious country with a leading education system. What’s more, our wide access to technology doesn’t put us above others in terms of successful education, which shows that our motivation for higher education can’t simply be increased with higher quality options. This means that for the U.S to be considered truly one of the leading countries in education, we need to increase motivation for education, by providing more successful post-education opportunities that reward the completion of education of all levels.

This is how the O.E.C.D. determines educational mobility: Intergenerational mobility is the intergenerational mobility in educational attainment between children and their parents. For example, if a respondent has completed a higher level of education than the highest educational level achieved by a parent, this is considered as upward mobility. Mobility can also be downward, meaning that the respondent’s highest level of education is below that of the parent with the highest educational attainment. Finally, the status quo means that the respondent has the same level of educational attainment as the parent with the highest educational attainment.
 What do you think of this method of calculating educational mobility comparing a child to the highest educational achievement by a parent

replies.name: g
replies.comment info:
@Connor I'll try to explain: Germany's education sytem is different from the US. You have A) the secondary school ( 9 years after elementary 's 4 years) Having passed  the final exams>( Abitur) you can go to a university without further tests. B) You can quit secondary after 8 years  and have access to specific universities offering a limited program of studies (mostly more technical). C) or you go to a" Realschule" for 6 years and then enter an apprenticeship  accompanied by a  professional school program ( dual education) and there some more  ways to get educated. So there is a relatively high but differentiated level of overall education which is not reflected by these statistics. 
And  we are definitely not happy with it, it needs reforms and some modernization. ... But that's a long story.

name: Malia
comment info:
In South Korea, there is more pressure for students to go into higher education. They are told that the only way to get a good job is to go to the best universities. Even after their school days, they spend hours at cram schools trying to improve their test scores. This factor could explain the graph on the left because students face an overbearing amount of pressure to make more money than their parents.  That begs the question, how much of a role does money play into young adults pursuing higher education? And what role does the government play in getting more people to pursue higher education? For example, in Denmark, the country pays for students to pursue higher education. This is kind of confusing because why is Denmark lower on the list. It also makes me question, what kind of social pressures are put on students from countries closer to the top of the graph to pursue higher education to their parents?
For the graph on the right, it looks like it is exemplifying the shift from men to women pursuing higher education. This might question if women are pursuing higher(college) education because of gender discrimination in thee workplace?

name: Anne C
comment info: Students in South Korea and southeast Asia, in general, feel more pressure to pursue a higher education. On the right graph, it is clear that the percentage of women in every country are pursuing a higher education than men. Does maturity play a large role in this data? Cost for higher education varies country to country- does this also play a large role? Do people in countries with a low cost higher education have more incentive to go to college? Also, the status quo must vary per family per country. If your parents went to college and you went to college, you received the same level of education. On the other hand, if your parents only completed a limited education (middle school, rather than high school or college) and you got a college education, you are part of the upwardly mobile trend. At some point, if everyone receives a higher education as do their parents, the status quo section will increase until the entire graph is the same or less, rather than a ix of all 3. I think this is why Italy is so high on the left graph, and so low on the right one; students may be doing better than their parents, but not at a level higher than high school.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Anne C Excellent observations, you seem to be very knowledgeable of the education system. Do you think the time between the when children received their education compared to their parents also played a role in the amount of education each received? In other words, do you think changes in curriculum have affected the amount of education both groups have received?

A thoughtful notice:  “If everyone receives a higher education as do their parents, the status quo section will increase until the entire graph is the same or less, rather than a ix of all 3.”  Do you think this is what is happening in the United States?  Or, is there another story here, that maybe we can see fro the right chart?

Cost for higher education varies country to country- does this also play a large role? Do people in countries with a low cost higher education have more incentive to go to college? Also, the status quo must vary per family per country. If your parents went to college and you went to college, you received the same level of education. On the other hand, if your parents only completed a limited education (middle school, rather than high school or college) and you got a college education, you are part of the upwardly mobile trend. At some point, if everyone receives a higher education as do their parents, the status quo section will increase until the entire graph is the same or less, rather than a ix of all 3.
